segment.source: Apply Images Using DISM
segment.target: Apply Images Using DISM

segment.source: Apply Images Using DISM
segment.target: Apply Images Using DISM

segment.source: Apply Images Using DISM
segment.target: Apply Images Using DISM

segment.source: This topic describes how to deploy images captured from your reference computer to one or more destination computers using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool.
segment.target: This topic describes how to deploy images captured from your reference computer to one or more destination computers using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool.

segment.source: For more information about configuring recommended hard drive partitions, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions and Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions.
segment.target: For more information about configuring recommended hard drive partitions, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions and Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions.

segment.source: Apply a Windows Image
segment.target: Apply a Windows Image

segment.source: On the destination computer, you will create a structure for the partitions where you apply your images.
segment.target: On the destination computer, you will create a structure for the partitions where you apply your images.

segment.source: The partition structure on the destination computer must match the partition structure of the reference computer.
segment.target: The partition structure on the destination computer must match the partition structure of the reference computer.

segment.source: If you apply an image to a volume with an existing Windows installation, files from the previous installation may not be deleted.
segment.target: If you apply an image to a volume with an existing Windows installation, files from the previous installation may not be deleted.

segment.source: Format the volume by using a tool such as DiskPart before applying the new image.
segment.target: Format the volume by using a tool such as DiskPart before applying the new image.

segment.source: To partition the hard drive and apply an image
segment.target: To partition the hard drive and apply an image

segment.source: Boot the destination computer to Windows PE.
segment.target: Boot the destination computer to Windows PE.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows PE (WinPE) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows PE (WinPE) Technical Reference.

segment.source: Connect to the network distribution share where your Windows image is stored.
segment.target: Connect to the network distribution share where your Windows image is stored.

segment.source: For example, you can use the net use command to do this:
segment.target: For example, you can use the net use command to do this:

segment.source: If prompted, provide your network credentials.
segment.target: If prompted, provide your network credentials.

segment.source: At the Windows PE command prompt, type to start the Diskpart tool.
segment.target: At the Windows PE command prompt, type to start the Diskpart tool.

segment.source: Create your partition structure using the Diskpart tool.
segment.target: Create your partition structure using the Diskpart tool.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: This example temporarily assigns these drive letters: Windows=C, System=S, and Recovery=R.
segment.target: This example temporarily assigns these drive letters: Windows=C, System=S, and Recovery=R.

segment.source: If you’re deploying to PCs with unformatted hard drives, change the Windows drive letter to a letter that’s near the end of the alphabet, such as W, to avoid drive letter conflicts.
segment.target: If you’re deploying to PCs with unformatted hard drives, change the Windows drive letter to a letter that’s near the end of the alphabet, such as W, to avoid drive letter conflicts.

segment.source: Do not use X, because this drive letter is reserved for Windows PE.
segment.target: Do not use X, because this drive letter is reserved for Windows PE.

segment.source: After the PC reboots, the Windows partition is assigned the letter C, and the other partitions don’t receive drive letters.
segment.target: After the PC reboots, the Windows partition is assigned the letter C, and the other partitions don’t receive drive letters.

segment.source: For examples of recommended partition structures, see Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions and Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.
segment.target: For examples of recommended partition structures, see Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions and Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can automate this task with the command.
segment.target: You can automate this task with the command.

segment.source: For more information, see Diskpart Command line syntax.
segment.target: For more information, see Diskpart Command line syntax.

segment.source: Use the DISM tool to apply images to your Windows partition.
segment.target: Use the DISM tool to apply images to your Windows partition.

segment.source: For each partition that you apply an image to, run the DISM/apply-image /imageFile: imagefile /index:indexnumber /ApplyDir:imagepath command.
segment.target: For each partition that you apply an image to, run the DISM/apply-image /imageFile: imagefile /index:indexnumber /ApplyDir:imagepath command.

segment.source: Note If the DISM /Apply-Image command fails, make sure you’re using a supported version of DISM for that Windows image.
segment.target: Note If the DISM /Apply-Image command fails, make sure you’re using a supported version of DISM for that Windows image.

segment.source: For example, to apply a Windows 10 image, you’ll need the Windows 10 version of DISM.
segment.target: For example, to apply a Windows 10 image, you’ll need the Windows 10 version of DISM.

segment.source: To set up a basic system partition, you can use the BCDboot tool to copy a simple set of system files to a system partition.
segment.target: To set up a basic system partition, you can use the BCDboot tool to copy a simple set of system files to a system partition.

segment.source: These files include boot configuration data (BCD) information that is used to start Windows:
segment.target: These files include boot configuration data (BCD) information that is used to start Windows:

segment.source: Use the BCDboot tool to copy common system partition files and to initialize boot configuration data:
segment.target: Use the BCDboot tool to copy common system partition files and to initialize boot configuration data:

segment.source: For more information about the BCDboot tool, see BCDboot Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about the BCDboot tool, see BCDboot Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can also set up the system partition by applying an image.
segment.target: You can also set up the system partition by applying an image.

segment.source: Use the DISM/apply-image command.
segment.target: Use the DISM/apply-image command.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: You can set up the computer to reinstall your Windows image in the event of a system failure.
segment.target: You can set up the computer to reinstall your Windows image in the event of a system failure.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) Technical Reference.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Microsoft Reserved partitions (MSR) and Extended partitions are managed by the computer.
segment.target: Microsoft Reserved partitions (MSR) and Extended partitions are managed by the computer.

segment.source: Do not apply an image to these partitions.
segment.target: Do not apply an image to these partitions.

segment.source: You can use audit mode to test the computer and to perform additional customizations before you ship it to your end user.
segment.target: You can use audit mode to test the computer and to perform additional customizations before you ship it to your end user.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.

segment.source: You can also perform some customizations to the computer without booting it.
segment.target: You can also perform some customizations to the computer without booting it.

segment.source: For more information, see Service an Applied Windows Image.
segment.target: For more information, see Service an Applied Windows Image.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you receive the error message: Bootmgr not found. Press CTRL+ALT+DEL, this indicates that Windows cannot identify the boot information in the active partition.
segment.target: If you receive the error message: Bootmgr not found. Press CTRL+ALT+DEL, this indicates that Windows cannot identify the boot information in the active partition.

segment.source: If you receive this error message, check the following:
segment.target: If you receive this error message, check the following:

segment.source: Use the DiskPart tool to check to make sure that the system partition is set to Active.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart tool to check to make sure that the system partition is set to Active.

segment.source: Check to make sure that the active partition includes system files.
segment.target: Check to make sure that the active partition includes system files.
